user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueueGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_QueueGetInfo(osal_id_t queue_id, OS_queue_prop_t *queue_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(queue_prop);

    memset(queue_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_queue_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, queue_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_queue_table, token);

        strncpy(queue_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(queue_prop->name) - 1);
        queue_prop->creator = record->creator;

        /*
         * Currently there are no additional queue details provided by the impl layer -
         * But this could be added in the future (i.e. current/max depth, msg size, etc)
         */

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_QueueGetInfo:
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
} OS_queue_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_queue_table
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
strncpy(queue_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(queue_prop->name) - 1);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No — not violated. In this code queue_prop->name is char[OS_MAX_API_NAME] and the code copies at most sizeof(queue_prop->name)-1 bytes. The destination size is respected (n <= dest size) and the whole queue_prop structure is zeroed by the preceding memset, so the result is guaranteed to be null-terminated. Given the usual implementation where record->name_entry is the same-sized name storage (OS_MAX_API_NAME) in the OS record, strncpy will not read or write beyond the bounds. (A violation would only occur if record->name_entry pointed to a smaller buffer than sizeof(queue_prop->name)-1 or to a non-terminated region smaller than that — that is not the case with the provided definitions.)
